direction.raw_text: on AARON (CHRIS ROCK) thirties, dressed in a black suit and tie. He looks straight ahead with a somber expression. The camera pulls back to reveal he is watching FOUR UNDERTAKERS (INCLUDING BRIAN) place a coffin on a raised platform. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Would you like to see... Aaron nods his head "yes", as BRIAN begins to open the coffin. Aaron crosses to the coffin. There's a dramatic moment as Aaron moves to the coffin and braces himself for what he's about to see. The coffin opens and Aaron stares long and hard at the body.

direction.raw_text: Brian... who is that?

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?

direction.raw_text: Who is this man I'm looking at? 'Cause it's not my father.

direction.raw_text: Are you sure?

direction.raw_text: Are you asking me if I'm sure I know what my father looks like?

direction.raw_text: People make mistakes in times of grief.

direction.raw_text: Man, look at the damn body! Brian peers into the coffin. We see it's an ASIAN MAN.

direction.raw_text: Oh shit! The other undertakers look embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Brian. You know what my father looks like. He used to take you to little league.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, man. I got a little nervous. This almost never happens. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's happened before?! You mean this is a normal thing?... This isn't Burger King. You can't just mess up my order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I know where he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I better .,see my dad in this coffin in an hour, or you're going to take his place. The undertakers pick up the coffin and shuffle out awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry. I'll get him, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do that. (TO HIMSELF) My people, my people, my people...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron enters the bedroom. His wife, MICHELLE, also thirties, attractive, is putting on makeup with a thermometer hanging from her mouth. Aaron stands looking dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They brought the wrong body. Can you believe that? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (muffled because of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wrong body?! Do they know where he is?

direction.raw_text: They think so. They're getting him now. The thermometer beeps and Michelle removes it from her mouth..

direction.raw_text: I told you not to use Marshals. But no, you wanted to keep it in the neighborhood. I know Swartz costs a little more, but at least they know where the bodies are. Michelle writes something down on a piece of paper as Aaron crosses the room and sits on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were right. Please don't rub it in, not today. I've got so much to worry about. Michelle gets up and heads to the bathroom as Aaron takes out some index cards and looks them over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad insisted on having the funeral here, Mom's crying all the time, Ryan didn't help with anything, not like he ever does! Plus my eulogy sucks. I can't wait until this day is over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Oh come on, honey. I'm sure it's not that bad.

direction.raw_text: If it is, at least Dad's too dead to hear it. Michelle exits the bathroom.

direction.raw_text: Honey, it's going to be fine. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter what I write. All anybody's going to be thinking is "why isn't Ryan doing the eulogy? Even I'm going to be thinking it. She holds him close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Baby, you're the oldest. You have to do the eulogy. Besides, I think you're just as good a writer as your brother. You just need to let someone read your book. Aaronlooks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soon. It's not ready to be read yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure it's fine. Once the funeral's over, and everything dies
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron gives her a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. Look, once this is all over, you know your mom's thinking about selling the house, so you know we've got to get out.of here. Aaron looks a little uncomfortable and heads to the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You called them, right? Silence from Aaron in the next room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron?... You put the down payment on the condo, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) I said I'd take care of it and I'll take care of it. Michelle looks frustrated and crosses into the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron is at the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better, because I can't live with your mother anymore. I've done my time, now it's time for your brother to take over. From now on, it's only Christmas and birthdays for us. Once we move, we can concentrate on your writing and our baby. Michelle gets down on her knees and starts unzipping Aaron's pants. Aaron pulls back.

direction.raw_text: Hey, hey, hey. Are you serious? We have to do this today? Michelle is still on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Today's the last day of this cycle.

direction.raw_text: Can I at least find the body first?

direction.raw_text: black, slightly heavier and riddled with anxiety, is driving. His friend, DEREK, an attractive, white, clean cut doctor, rides in the passenger seat.

direction.raw_text: I hate funerals. It's all death, death, death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think funerals are designed for anybody to really like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want a regular funeral. When I die, I want people to celebrate my life. (CONTINUED) Death at a Funeral 02/6/09 CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me. I want it to be the saddest day ever. I want the stock market to stop. Schools to close. And no garbage pick-up. Derek starts to light a cigarette.

direction.raw_text: You still smoke?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You used to smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to piss my pants too, but I stopped. The only thing I want black is my skin. At least open the window. Derek opens the window very slightly.

direction.raw_text: I've got enough problems of my own to deal with.

direction.raw_text: Yeah? What problems?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you... About the rash...

direction.raw_text: Got to use condoms.

direction.raw_text: .on my hand...

direction.raw_text: Still got to use condoms.

direction.raw_text: Look at it. Norman pulls up his sleeve and makes Derek look at his wrist, but he doesn't take a great deal of interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not a rash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? (CONTINUED) B.

direction.raw_text: I don't know, but it doesn't look right.

direction.raw_text: Oh, damn. Norman continues to drive. Derek continues to smoke.

direction.raw_text: Are you okay?

direction.raw_text: Yeah, just a little nervous...

direction.raw_text: About seeing my dad?

direction.raw_text: At least you know it's not you, so try not to get so nervous when he's around.

direction.raw_text: He's going to be more.concerned that his brother-in-law just died. He won't be focused on you. Anyway, when I tell him we're getting married, he'll have to accept you. Elaine takes his hand. As they exchange a loving look, Oscar takes his eyes off the road for just a brief moment. Suddenly there's a BUMP!!! And we see a bicyclist flying over Oscar's car. Oscar screeches to a halt. They jump out of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God. Are you okay? The guy gets up. He's fine.

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I'm fine.

direction.raw_text: Are you sure? Is anything broken? I'm so sorry.

direction.raw_text: It was my fault. I ran a light. Oscar starts hyperventilating.

direction.raw_text: I could have killed you. What if you had cracked your head open? I'd have blood on my hands! Elaine shakes him.

direction.raw_text: Oscar, calm down! (BEAT) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I found them. The ones in the Valium bottle?... Yeah... I'll get them to you this evening... Can't do this afternoon... It's your fault you left them here... I've got a funeral... My uncle died... Yeah, tragic... No, I haven't taken any. I saw what they did to you... What are they anyway?... The doorbell rings.

direction.raw_text: Here. Take this..: It'll calm you down.

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just Valium. (gets a glass of water) I used to take them all the time... It'll make you feel better, promise. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Are you sure? I mean, I've got to drive.

direction.raw_text: It'll be okay. I'll drive, honey. Come on, open wide. She pops the pill in his mouth and hands him some water. Oscar swallows. Jeff returns wearing pants.

direction.raw_text: There he is. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: When does dead beat sick?

direction.raw_text: I guess you're right. This is why I try not to get close to people. There's too much emotion involved.

direction.raw_text: Well that explains why you never call.

direction.raw_text: What do you want me to say? Some families talk to each other all the time, some just see each other at funerals. That's us.

direction.raw_text: Oh, right. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Nice to see you again. The mourner shakes hands with Ryan then walks away.

direction.raw_text: Who are all these people? I don't even recognize half of them.

direction.raw_text: It's your family. You don't recognize them from the last funeral? Ryan looks around the room.

direction.raw_text: So what side of the family is he on?

direction.raw_text: Who?

direction.raw_text: The guy in the leather jacket. Ryan looks around the room and sees a FOUR FOOT SIX MAN (FRANK) approaching the coffin.

direction.raw_text: I have no idea. Maybe a friend of Dad's from work or something. Aaron turns to Ryan.

direction.raw_text: No I'm telling you you'll have the money in a few months when I get my advance.

direction.raw_text: I'm not a God damn credit agency!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a very calm, serene woman, suddenly appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron, how are you? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, um... We're just waiting for everyone to arrive, then we can get going. I know you're in a hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I have two more funerals and a Christening. I don't know what it is about the Spring, but they're either coming in or going out. She laughs, but Aaron and Ryan just look at her. Reverend Davis stands there waiting to be introduced to Ryan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you met my brother, Ryan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, the writer, of course. I must admit I squeezed this job in because I wanted to meet you. I'm reading "Mama's Secret" right now. Don't tell anybody, I'm not supposed to be reading that kind of stuff.

direction.raw_text: I'm sure the Lord will forgive you. Aaron is irritated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must be very proud of your big brother. He really made something of his life. (TO RYAN) I can't wait to hear your eulogy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, I'm doing the eulogy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I thought...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaron is the oldest. The reverend tries her best not to look disappointed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great... Well, I'll just make sure have everything I need. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at the coffin and then at the Bible in her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got a body and a Bible. Well, I'm all set. She walks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I think you should do the eulogy. Everyone's expecting you to do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, they're not. You're the oldest. You should do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look most of the people are here for Dad, but let's not kid ourselves. A lot of them are here to hear your eulogy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So imagine how surprised they'll be when they hear yours. Ryan walks away.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's my little sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying to hold it together, Duncan. He was a really good husband. My friends always told me about the crap their husbands put them through. I never had to deal with any of that. Remember when Uncle Matt got that nanny pregnant?

direction.raw_text: That was horrible. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: They don't make 'em like my Edward anymore. A good husband and a great father to two healthy, strong boys. Michelle cringes in the background.

direction.raw_text: I'll make you a cup of coffee, Cynthia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffee can do many things Michelle, but it can't bring back the dead. Beat.

direction.raw_text: Tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "My father was an exceptional man... My father was an exceptional man... My father was an exceptional man..." Michelle approaches him.

direction.raw_text: Honey, we still need to finish that thing. Remember today is the last day.

direction.raw_text: No. No we can't.

direction.raw_text: Honey, I'm just not in the mood...

direction.raw_text: I don't have any panties on. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: I'm just trying to help you out. I'll put them back on before the service starts. Now come on. They turn. Aaron looks around the corner into the living room and sees the four foot six man standing by a table. Aaron stops Michelle.

direction.raw_text: No, no, that's not it. He keeps looking at me. Don't look. Don't look.

direction.raw_text: He's probably just a friend of your father's. I'll meet you in the garage. We have a few minutes before Uncle Russell gets here. Michelle walks off. Aaron peeks around the corner again and makes eye contact with the four foot six inch man, who seems to be staring straight at him. Aaron averts his eyes and heads off.

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?! Be careful with that. Uncle Russell bangs his cane on the floor impatiently.

direction.raw_text: Can you keep an eye out for Uncle Russell?

direction.raw_text: Something like that, yeah. Michelle sticks her head out of the kitchen.

direction.raw_text: Honey. Can I see you for a moment?

direction.raw_text: .Of course.

direction.raw_text: It's so nice to see you.

direction.raw_text: No, don't do that. It'll just freak him out... We'll just keep a close eye on him, and make sure he doesn't get out of control... direction.raw_text: What are you going to do?

direction.raw_text: I don't know. I can't leave. Aunt Cynthia would never speak to me again. Jeff notices that Oscar has left. He rushes outside. Elaine follows. Derek follows suit.

direction.raw_text: I'm dressed for a funeral.

direction.raw_text: So, I heard about the engagement.

direction.raw_text: Hey, hey. I don't really have time to deal with whatever happened between you and me. But I have not told my dad yet, so I would appreciate it if you would keep your mouth shut.

direction.raw_text: Sure. Anything for you. Derek looks over and notices Oscar looking bewildered.

direction.raw_text: So that's him? That's the man you're going to spend the rest of your life with? Elaine looks over at the drugged up Oscar. Oscar leans over like he's on a nod. Jeff leans down with him, watching. Right before Oscar falls over, he comes up really fast.- Then he starts walking.

direction.raw_text: Yep, that's him. Oscar who has been walking in circles with a look of awe on his face, changes direction and flies by Elaine and Derek back into the house with Jeff in tow. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: My father was an exceptional man... My father was-- Frank again approaches Aaron.

direction.raw_text: Actually, there's something I'd like to talk to you about... when you have a minute. Aaron hears Uncle Russell in the background.

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that's great. Do you mind if we do it later though? My uncle just got here.

direction.raw_text: Sure. Aaron heads off.

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Derek, you're a life saver. Hope it wasn't too much trouble.

direction.raw_text: Can I get a little help?

direction.raw_text: Move! Move! He pokes people with his cane. Aaron then takes his seat with Michelle. Oscar is not looking so good. Ryan finally ends the conversation with Martina and heads to his seat. Reverend Davis is about to start, but waits as Norman, sweating, pushes through the crowd to his seat. The reverend waits for the disturbance to end, so Norman attracts the attention of everyone. Norman takes his seat next to Derek. Derek leans away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You stink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Family and friends, we're gathered here today to mourn the passing of Edward Barnes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, you left me to push Uncle Russell up that damn hill all by myself. Then took all the credit. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Elaine, turns around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Norman, shut up. Elaine turns back around. Norman is irritated by this.

direction.raw_text: I'd like to start with a favorite passage of Edwards from First Samuel chapter 18, verses 1-4 in the King James Bible. (READING) "And it came to pass, when he had made an end of speaking unto Saul, that the soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul. And Saul took him that day, and would let him go no more home to his father's house..." While the reverend is talking, Norman pokes Elaine on the shoulder and leans forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Elaine, I know you don't think I'm part of the family--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cause you're not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .but when you dissed me back there, I had Uncle Russell in the car. Aaron, disturbed by Norman's whispering, looks over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You stole my parking space, and I had to push him half a mile up a hill. We almost missed the service! Aaronlooks over again.

direction.raw_text: Look, Norman, if you poke me one more time, I'm going to kick your ass. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is going on?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stole my parking space!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers to Norman) Stole your parking space?!. My father's dead! Act right. Reverend Davis looks at them then continues her speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ."Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, because he loved him as his own soul..." As she speaks, Norman looks at his wrist, worried. The woman sitting next to him smacks his wrist down.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: Aaron and Michelle. Aaron looks worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ."And Jonathan stripped himself of the robe that was upon him, and gave it to David, and his garments, even to his sword and to his bow, and to his girdle."

direction.raw_text: ON: Oscar is laughing. Elaine tries to control him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now we'll have a few words from Edward's son, Aaron. Ryan's older brother.

direction.raw_text: ON: Aaron as he gathers himself. Michelle gives Aaron a supportive squeeze of the arm. Aaron looks over and sees Frank staring at him.

direction.raw_text: ON: Uncle Russell.

direction.raw_text: Why isn't Ryan doing the eulogy? This is bullshit. (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon, everyone. (his voice cracks) Thank you for coming... I never realized Dad was so popular. It looks like he's got more friends now that he's dead. Blank faces stare back at Aaron. Cynthia looks pained. Everyone is silent except for Oscar who laughs loudly. Elaine silences him with a look. Aaron composes himself and pulls his notes out.

direction.raw_text: My father was an exceptional man... He was born in 1938. He grew up in Alabama on a farm. He loved to take long walks in the woods with his close friend, Bobby. He told me how they spent their summer days riding their bikes through the fields and swimming in the lake. As Aaron speaks, Reverend Davis looks concerned because the eulogy is so bad. She looks to Ryan who looks like "what can I do?" Jeff looks more concerned with Oscar, whose face is contorted with pain. He looks like he's going to burst.

direction.raw_text: ON: Aaron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad's first job was working after school as an assistant to an electrician named Mr. Thompson. Back then, Blacks weren't allowed to wear rubber gloves. So my father got shocked a lot. Because of that, he had no feeling in his fingertips. I asked my Dad what his first boss was like... The drugs have gotten the best of Oscar. He suddenly grabs Elaine's arm. Aaron keeps talking.

direction.raw_text: Did you just see that? (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: See what?

direction.raw_text: What?

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you I saw it move. Aaron becomes vaguely aware of the disturbance, but battles on with his eulogy.

direction.raw_text: .He said he was a nice man, and surprisingly well dressed. When Dad was eighteen, he left home after an argument with his father. He never told me what that argument was about, but I do know that after leaving South Carolina, sadly he and Bob lost touch and never saw each other again. Dad went to college where he studied accounting, a decision which lead to a career in corporate finance... But his real passion was for the arts, with a particular fondness for theatre, dance and musicals. He was a charter member of the Negro Ensemble Company and contributed regularly to the Alvin Ailey School of Dance. Oscar's protests are getting louder. Duncan looks back at the disruption with a disapproving glare. Elaine looks at Jeff who watches, concerned.

direction.raw_text: There, look. It happened again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oscar, please- People start looking at Oscar, who's becoming increasingly vocal, and looking increasingly like someone on acid.

direction.raw_text: That coffin's moving! (CONTINUED)

direction.raw_text: Oscar. Just calm down. Aaron looks over to Oscar.

direction.raw_text: The coffin's moving! Michelle looks worried. Cynthia watches silently. Oscar jumps up. Aaron stops the eulogy. Elaine is about to die from embarrassment.

direction.raw_text: There's someone alive in there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oscar, please sit down. Oscar ignores her and walks purposefully towards the coffin. People watch him in astonishment, including Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is wrong with you people?! Oscar approaches the coffin as Aaron steps off the dais. Elaine tries to hold Oscar back, but she can't.

direction.raw_text: Oscar, where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's your skin thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh that... It's probably nothing. I'm more worried about Hepatitis C after having Uncle Russell's shit in my mouth. I think I'm feeling yellow. Norman touches his skin as he walks away, leaving Derek confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: Jeff frantically looking for the pill bottle. He gives up and sits in a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: Ryan is wheeling Uncle Russell into the room as Aaron moves to his seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you I saw the guy. He was dead!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you did, Russell. We all did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! In the bathroom. Ryan offers a look to the other mourners indicating that Uncle Russell's a bit mad and shouldn't be listened to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: Michelle comes over to Aaron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe what a nightmare today has been. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. It's been sort of exciting. Aaron looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a funeral, I mean...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, about the condo and the baby,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll work it out. Let's just get this day over with. Then we can worry about the rest of our lives. Aaron hugs Michelle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe I still have to do this eulogy... with everything I've just found out. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't change anything, does it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a thing. Reverend Davis approaches Aaron, looking at her watch and appearing flustered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to have to fly through this now. I already missed a funeral and two Christenings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want an open casket?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! The reverend looks shocked at the reaction, but ignores it. She stands up at the front and speaks quickly. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright! Everybody in their seats now! (she snaps her fingers) Hey, you, sit down. People settle into their seats. Ryan manages to squeeze in next to Martina. He smiles at her, flirtatiously. Cynthia throws Ryan a look, and he gets up and goes to sit with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (speaking very quickly) I'd like to apologize on behalf of the family for all of the distractions. I hope that everyone is settled and ready to continue with the service. Aaron, the oldest son, would like to say a few words about his father. Michelle gives Aaron an encouraging look as he makes his way to the front. Aaron clears his throat and prepares to begin. The room is absolutely silent. He takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: The reverend nodding for Aaron to hurry up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: Aaron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father... was an exceptional--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! BANG! BANG! Suddenly, a loud banging emanates from the coffin. Everyone stares at it in stunned silence. Jeff looks over to Norman whose eyes are as wide as saucers. Aaron looks like a deer caught in headlights. He looks at Ryan who gestures to him to continue. He nervously struggles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father was an exceptional man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! BANG! BANG! Everyone stares at the coffin in awe. Aaron bravely continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not only did he live for his family, but he was always there for others--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! BANG! BANG! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's someone in there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew it! I knew it! Suddenly the coffin lid flips off and everyone stares in wonder as Frank sits up, looking like a crazy person, and babbling incoherently. Several people scream. Frank opens the other end of the coffin and looks at his dead lover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to cover) What the hell are you doing in my Dad's coffin? Frank starts grabbing at Edward's body screaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward! Edward! Edward! Ryan, Norman and Jeff try to pull Frank out of the coffin, but he's holding onto the corpse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! No! Finally they get Frank out and carry him from the room. As he passes Cynthia, the photos fall out of his pocket at her feet. As Duncan closes the coffin again, Cynthia bends down and picks up one of the photographs and stares at it. Her face turns to horror as she makes out the image. The noise in the room is broken by Cynthia's furious cry. She drops the photos and runs at Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bastard! Cynthia tackles Frank and starts beating him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as she hits him) He was with you! Duncan picks up the photos. He shows them to Uncle Russell. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always thought he had a little sugar in his tank. Everything has descended into total chaos until Aaron finally shouts across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !!! Everyone, including Frank and Cynthia, looks at Aaron, stunned. They all freeze. There's a long silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had his... shortcomings, but he took care of his family. He loved his family. He loved this house. He worked hard. All I wanted today was to show him how much we all loved and admired him. To give him the respect that he deserved... Is that really so much to ask? We all get so distracted by the... little things in life. We forget about the important things. Like the fact that we lost a great man. The mourners look up at Aaron with undivided attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So maybe he loved "Dreamgirls" more than most men. We don't know why a man makes the choices he makes. But I do know that my father made the best choices he could make. Life is complicated. We're just thrown here together in a world filled with chaos and confusion... and we do our best. And Dad did his best... Aaron looks over at the coffin. As.he speaks, we see shots of Cynthia, Frank, Jeff, Norman, Duncan as they are moved by Aaron's words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He taught us to go for what we wanted in life, because you never know how long you're going to be here... And whether you succeed... or you fail... the important thing is that you tried. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: AARON MY FATHER WAS AN EXCEPTIONAL MAN

direction.raw_text: A beat. Michelle looks up at her husband with pride. We see the various other mourners looking at Aaron and listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So when you all leave here today, I want you to remember Dad for who he really was... A decent, loving man who never condemned anyone for how they lived. Who never cast disparaging remarks or held prejudices against race, gender... height. If only we could all be as giving, as generous, as understanding as my father... Even dead, my father has more character than everyone in this room. If I am half the man my father was, my child will be incredibly blessed. Aaron turns and walks out of the room. Everyone watches him go. Michelle follows him out of the room.
direction.name: direction
